questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used specifically for reversal of rocuronium induced muscle relaxation?
questions.solution:
Ans: C
•	Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin molecule.
•	It’s a specific antagonist for steroidal NDMR rocuronium & vecuronium.
•	It causes instant reversal.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics is associated with the highest risk of cardiotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) Bupivacaine

Explanation:  Bupivacaine has a high risk of cardiotoxicity, especially when administered in high doses or accidentally injected intravenously, leading to severe arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Which oxygen delivery system provides fixed fio2?

questions.text: Which of the following is a benzodiazepine antagonist?
questions.solution:
Ans: B
Flumazenil is a specific benzodiazepine receptor antagonist and used to reverse benzodiazepine toxicity and reverse respiratory depression because of it.

questions.text: Which of the following agents act on NMDA receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans: C
Ketamine is a NMDA receptor antagonist.

questions.text: Which brachial plexus block approach is most suitable for surgery on the shoulder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  A) Interscalene block

Explanation:  The interscalene block is ideal for shoulder surgeries as it anesthetizes the upper roots of the brachial plexus (C5-C7), which innervate the shoulder.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct order of route of loss of heat during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans: C
•	Intraoperative hypothermia is a common complication during anesthesia
•	Body loses heat by different routes and the order for same is:
Radiation > convection > conduction > evaporation

questions.text: Anesthetic gas with maximum respiratory irritation

Ans: C
Inhaled anesthetic agent which in pungent in odour are:
•	Ether

•	Desflurane (maximum)

questions.text: Which of the following is the inhalational anesthetic agent of choice for induction & maintenance of anesthesia in children?
questions.solution:
Ans: D

One main disadvantage of halothane is its high blood:gas partition coefficient, which leads to relatively long induction times. 
It also can produce cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial depression, and halothane-induced hepatitis. 
Because of the inability to achieve deep levels of anesthesia with halothane because of its side effects, the use of nmbds, opioids, or both, is often required

questions.text: Which local anesthetic is known for causing methemoglobinemia as a potential adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prilocaine

Explanation: Prilocaine is associated with the risk of methemoglobinemia, especially when used in high doses. This condition impairs the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin.

questions.text: Halothane causes malignant hyperthermia by affecting which channels?
questions.solution:
Ans: B
Malignant hyperthermia is a hypermetabolic muscle disorder due to genetic mutation in the ryanodine receptor.
The mutation is seen most commonly in chromosome 19.
This mutation causes uncontrolled release of calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum causing intense muscle contractions and subsequent complications of hypermetabolism.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine, for supraclavicular brachial plexus block & suddenly developed hypotension & arrythmias. Which of the following is correct 1st line treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans: B
LAST : LOCAL ANESTHETIC SYSTEMIC TOXICITY.
Agent of choice for CVS last is iv intralipid.

questions.text: Tuffier’s line corresponds to which level?
questions.solution:
Ans: C
Tuffier’s line is a line joining highest points of iliac crest.
This corresponds to the intervertebral level between L4-L5 or body of L4.
This serves as a surface landmark for needle injection point for spinal anesthesia as spinal cord ends at L1 in adults and L3 in children.

Give rescue breath, se pulse, start CPR
Assess patient, activate emergency response team and call for help, start CPR

questions.solution: Ans. C

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is metabolized by Hoffman’s elimination?
questions.solution:
Ans: option B
Atracurium and cis atracurium are unique drugs that get metabolized by a non-organ dependant process called as Hoffman’s elimination.
This is spontaneous degradation of molecule under physiological ph and temperature.
Because of this metabolism, both are considered to be agent of choice for patients with renal and hepatic failure.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve fibers are most sensitive to the action of local anesthetics?

NPO for 8 hours irrespective of last meal.

questions.text: Before Laparoscopic surgery, what advise should be given to the patient by surgeon?
questions.solution:
Ans: C

ASA fasting guidelines for elective surgical cases are based on the type of food taken by the patient before surgery and not just in terms of number of hours.

choices.text: Do not use an AED on an infant

questions.text: Where should you place the AED pads when treating an infant for pediatric cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
Ans: A
•    An AED can be used on children and infants and should be used as early as possible for the best chance of improving survival. 
•    Check the AED when it arrives at the scene. 
•    Pediatric pads should be used if the person is less than eight years old. 
•    Standard (adult) pads may be used if pediatric pads are not available. 
•    If using standard (adult) pads, do not let the pads touch. 
•    For infants less than a year old, a manual defibrillator should be used if available. If a manual defibrillator is not available, an AED may be used. 
•    If the AED cannot deliver a pediatric shock, an adult shock should be given.

choices.text: omit the morning dose of both insulin and glimepiride and continue antihypertensives
omit all medications on the day of surgery
continue all medications on the day of surgery
omit insulin, glimepiride and telmisartan and continue amlodipine on the day of surgery

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who is a known case of diabetes and hypertension is posted for an elective laparoscopic hernioplasty and takes regular insulin and oral glimepiride for his diabetes and tablet telmisartan and amlodipine for his hypertension. What would be the pre-operative advice you will give to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans: D

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman undergoes total knee arthroplasty under spinal anesthesia. Two days later she complains of a severe headache. Pain intensity is related to posture. The MOST likely cause of this headache is
questions.solution:
Ans (D) 
•	PDPH is due to a loss of CSF through a dural puncture and characteristically has a postural component.
•	When supine, the headache is usually gone but may be mild in some cases. 
•	When the head is elevated, the headache may be severe, is bilateral, and may be associated with diplopia, nausea, and vomiting.
•	The headache pain is typically frontal and/or occipital in location. 
•	Typically the onset of the headache is 12 to 24 hours after a dural puncture and lasts several days if untreated (rarely it can last for months).
•	The other headaches listed rarely have a significant postural component

questions.text: Which scoring system is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B
Mallampati classification is one of the methods to predict difficult airway and is a part of airway assessment.
The patient is instructed to open the mouth wide and protrude tongue with no phonation .
Intra oral structures are visualized , i.e pillars, uvula, soft palate & hard palate.
Based on relative visualization of these structures Mallampati classes are I,II,III & IV.
I ,II are easy airways
III& IV are difficult

choices.text: After every two cycles of CPR
After every five cycles of CPR

questions.text: When performing two-rescuer CPR, how often should you switch roles?
questions.solution:
25: Ans: C
•	Changing roles after every cycle of CPR will create too many interruptions and impair successful resuscitation. 
•	Changing roles after every 2 cycles of CPR will create frequent interruptions in perfusion and is not consistent with AHA recommendations. 
•	Changing roles after every 5 cycles of CPR is the currently recommended frequency to promote high quality CPR. 
•	CPR is physically demanding and waiting to switch roles every 10 cycles will likely fatigue the rescuer performing chest compressions resulting in lower quality CPR.

questions.text: After a failed attempt at direct laryngoscopy for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the anesthesiologist decided to insert a supraglottic airway device to keep oxygenating the patient. According to difficult airway association (DAS) guidelines which plan is this?
questions.solution: Ans C

questions.text: Identify the image?
questions.solution:
Ans: B
•	Defibrillation involves delivery of current through the chest and to the heart to depolarize myocardial cells simultaneously and eliminate VF. 
•	As soon as an AED/Defibrillator is available attach and defibrillate if indicated
•	AED (Automated external defibrillator) is a computerized completely automatic defibrillator which uses voice and visual prompts to guide lay rescuers and healthcare providers to safely defibrillate. 
•	They can automatically analyze cardiac rhythm, charge to appropriate energy level and shock if advised. 
•	This is the single greatest advance in CPR which has significantly reduced in and out of hospital mortality after SCA. 
•	Due to the increasing evidence for improved survival with early defibrillation and the introduction of AEDs, defibrillation which was earlier part of ACLS, has been now included as part of BLS. 
•	All AEDs are biphasic and are not recommended for use under the age of one year.

questions.text: There is a sick patient in ward who needs supplemental oxygen. It will be given from which of the following cylinder?
questions.solution: Ans: A

questions.text: What is the order of steps to be performed for an effective resuscitation according to adult chain of survival guidelines? 1: Rapid defibrillation 2: post-cardiac arrest care 3: Early cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) with an emphasis on chest compressions 4: advanced resuscitation 5: Recognition of cardiac arrest and activation of the emergency response system
questions.solution: Ans: C

questions.text: Which of these is most commonly used as preanesthetic medication
questions.solution:
Ans. d. Glycopyrrolate
Pre anesthetic medication: 
This involves administration of drugs before the beginning to anesthesia to achieve desired goals.
Goals:
1)	Allay of anxiety
2)	To achieve amnesia of periop events. ( anterograde)
3)	Prevention of secretions ( anti sialogougue)
4)	Analgesia
5)	To decrease the dose of anesthetic agents.
6)	To prevent vasovagal response to anesthesia
7)	Prevent the aspiration of gastric contents ( anti aspiration)
8)	To prevent post operative nausea and vomiting ( anti emetic)
9)	To prevent anaphylactic / anaphyactoid reactions

Drugs used:
•	For sedation, anti anxiety and amnesia : benzodiazepines are drug of choice. Best agent is midazolam
•	For anti sialogougue effect : anticholinergics are doc . in that glycopyrrolate is best (quaternary ammonium compound so no central effects)
•	For post-operative nausea and vomiting : 5HT3 receptor antagonists are drug of choice : ondansetron is the best.

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agent is best for cardiac patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: C
Isoflurane causes least decrease in cardiac output and maximum decrease in systemic vascular resistance.
It is best agent to be used for cardiac patients.

questions.text: The circled part of the picture reflects;
questions.solution:
Ans: D
•    Capnography is measurement of end tidal carbondioxide concentration
•    Its normal value is 35-45 mmhg
•    Infrared spectroscopy is most common method of estimating ETCO2
•    This a typical capnographich waveform


Phase I: dead space gases ( No CO2)
Phase II: expiratory upstroke ( mixed dead space gas + alveolar CO2)
Phase III: plateau phase ( alveolar gas)
Phase 0: inspiration

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used topical anesthetic for surface anesthesia?

Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics (EMLA):

questions.text: Match the following clinical conditions with their appropriate capnography waveforms:
questions.solution: Ans: B

questions.text: Which of the following is most preferred for intravenous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA)?
questions.solution:
Ans: B
The Bier block, also known as intravenous local anesthesia (IVRA), is a safe, effective, and cost-efficient way to provide short-term anesthesia and analgesia during surgery on an extremity

The original attraction to IVRA is the simplicity of the block as well as the ability to perform the block with little additional equipment. 

It provides complete anesthesia, avoids general anesthetic, as well as a bloodless surgical field.

The volume of administration can vary based on the potency of the local anesthetic used. 

It has been common practice to use 30-50 ml of 0.5% Lidocaine without epinephrine. 

Although Lidocaine is the most used local anesthetic, others can be used to include prilocaine and chloroprocaine.

One local anesthetic that is not recommended for IVRA is bupivacaine due to its high cardiac toxicity and potential for cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Which of the following is most suitable for detecting myocardial ischemia during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) ECG

 Explanation:  ECG is the most effective tool for detecting myocardial ischemia during anesthesia, especially by monitoring for ST-segment changes that may indicate ischemia.

questions.text: Concerning sevoflurane:
questions.solution:
ANS:C
•	Sevoflurane is an inhalational anaesthetic agent with useful properties. 
•	These include its use in gaseous induction of anaesthesia owing to its lack of respiratory irritation. 
•	It’s a mild cardio depressant with no change in heart rate on induction and hypotension.
•	It has rapid onset and offset therefore making it an ideal agent in day case surgery and difficult airway situations.
•	It owes its rapid onset and offset to a blood:gas partition coefficient of 0.69. 
•	It is 3–5% metabolized. 
•	The toxicity of compound A has only been demonstrated in rats at high temperatures under conditions of prolonged low-flow anaesthesia. 
•	The toxicity of compound A has not been demonstrated in humans, even with low-flow anaesthesia.

questions.text: Rotameters are commonly seen on anaesthetic machines. Which of the following are true of these devices except?
questions.solution:
ANS: A
Rotameters: 
•    They are the part of anaesthesia machine that measures gas flow rates
•    It is a part of low-pressure system
•    It is usually a conical Pyrex glass tube
•    The bobbin or float inside the rotameter is made up of aluminium.
•    The principle of working is variable orifice and constant pressure
•    There is a anti static coating in the rota meter to prevent development of static electricity.

choices.text: Decrease bleeding in the surgical field

questions.text: Epinephrine is added to local anesthetics for all of the following reasons EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increase the onset time

Explanation: Epinephrine does not increase the onset time; rather, it prolongs the duration of action, reduces systemic absorption (thereby reducing toxicity), and decreases bleeding in the surgical field.

questions.text: For what purpose is the instrument given below used for?
questions.solution:
Ans b. Lumbar puncture

•	Spinal needles are commercially available in an array of sizes lengths, and bevel and tip designs. 
•	All should have a tightly fitting removable stylet that completely occludes the lumen to avoid tracking epithelial cells into the subarachnoid space. 
•	Broadly, they can be divided into either sharp (cutting)-tipped or blunt-tipped needles. 
•	The Quincke needle is a cutting needle with end injection. 
•	The introduction of blunt tip (pencil-point) needles has markedly decreased the incidence of postdural puncture headache. 
•	The Whitacre and Sprotte are pencil-point needles 
•	In general, the smaller the gauge needle, the lower the incidence of headache.

questions.text: Which complication is most commonly associated with supraclavicular approach to brachial plexus block?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  A) Pneumothorax

 Explanation:  Pneumothorax is a known complication of certain approaches to brachial plexus block, particularly the supraclavicular approach, as the pleura is in close proximity to the needle path

questions.text: The most reliable indicator of adequate ventilation in an intubated patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C) Capnography

 Explanation:  Capnography provides continuous monitoring of exhaled CO2, which is a direct indicator of ventilation. Chest movement and breath sounds can be misleading, and pulse oximetry lags behind in detecting hypoventilation

questions.text: A patient is experiencing a symptomatic new wide complex QRS rhythm that is unstable. Cardioversion is indicated. He has a high ASA risk score (unstable uncontrolled ischemic heart disease and diabetes) with a Mallampati score of 2. What is the most appropriate sedative agent for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans B 
•	Etomidate is frequently used for cardiac procedural sedation because it has limited effect on vital signs; there is essentially no cardiac stimulation or suppression.
•	Ketamine may raise heart rate and blood pressure. In the setting of a patient whose cardiac status is tenuous, elevating the heart rate may increase myocardial oxygen demand and thereby increase ischemia. 
•	Fentanyl, used alone, has good analgesic properties via a central mechanism (blunting frontal lobe function) but, in doses sufficient to make painful procedures tolerable, may suppress respirations. 
•	Propofol has a good analgesic and hypnotic properties, it drops peripheral vascular resistance and thus may cause a hypotension. This may compromise cardiac circulation, thus increasing ischemia and decreasing cardiac output

questions.text: Before endotracheal intubation, oxygenation given for how much time?
questions.solution:
ANSWER:  3 mins
•	Preoxygenation is typically performed via a facemask attached to either the anesthesia machine or a Mapleson circuit. 
•	To ensure adequate preoxygenation, 100% oxygen must be provided at a flow rate high enough to prevent rebreathing (10 to 12 L/min), and no leaks around the facemask must be present. 
•	An end-tidal concentration of oxygen greater than 90% is considered to maximize apnea time. 
•	Two primary methods are used to accomplish preoxygenation. The first method uses tidal volume ventilation through the facemask for 3 minutes, which allows the exchange of 95% of the gas in the lungs. 
•	The second method uses vital capacity breaths to achieve adequate preoxygenation more rapidly. Four breaths over 30 seconds is not as effective as the tidal volume method but may be acceptable in certain clinical situations; eight breaths over 60 seconds has been shown to be more effective.
•	Head-up positioning has been shown to improve the quality of preoxygenation in both obese and nonobese patients.

choices.text: agonist at glutamate at the NMDA receptor
Is metabolized to norketamine by liver

questions.text: Ketamine all are true except?
questions.solution:
48: B
•	Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative 
•	Although generally given intravenously, it has been used via the oral and rectal routes for sedation and also intrathecally or via the epidural route for prolonged analgesia. 
•	Ketamine antagonizes glutamate at the NMDA receptors within the central nervous system and, in contrast with most other anaesthetic agents, it has no activity at the GABA receptors. 
•	It produces a state of dissociated anaesthesia with intense analgesia and amnesia. 
•	Vivid dreams, delirium and hallucinations may follow its use. 
•	Cerebral blood flow, oxygen consumption and intracranial pressure (ICP) are all increased and this should be considered when dealing with patients with head injuries or raised ICP.

questions.text: IV administration of which anesthetic drug is most painful among the following.
questions.solution:
ANS: C
Pain on administration of drug in anesthesia are:
•	Etomidate (maximum)
•	Propofol
•	Diazepam
•	Lorazepam 
•	Thiopentone (>2.5%)

questions.text: Fastest acting inhalational anaesthetic agent:
questions.solution:
Ans: B
•    Speed of onset and recovery of an inhaled anesthetic agent is dependent on its solubility.
•    Solubility of an inhaled anesthetic agent is a function of its blood gas partition coefficient.
•    Blood gas partition coefficient is defined as the ratio of concentration of inhaled anesthetic agent in blood to alveoli at steady state.
•    More the solubility of an agent in blood, more will be its blood gas partition coefficient and slower will be its speed of onset and recovery.

questions.text: Person is under surgery for laryngeal malignancy, while ligating jugular vein he suddenly developed hypotension ventricular arrhythmia and sudden etco2 fall. Cause?
questions.solution:

venous air embolism..
Diagnosis based on the clinical picture and risk factors present.
✓Large central vein open to air
✓Sudden drop of etco2 while manipulating the large vein
✓head and neck surgery where the position of the patient is kept head up so the vein is above the level of the heart

As the name is suggestive, epidural anesthesia involves placing a catheter in the epidural space.
Since it is outside the Dural layer of meninges so it is essentially not pierced in it.
Layers pierced during epidural catheter placement (from outside to inside)
Skin>>> subcutaneous tissue>>> supraspinous ligament>>> interspinous ligament>>> ligamentum flavum

Propofol is considered best agent for TIVA.

Mallampati classification: used to assess difficulty in intubation.
Based on visualization of intraoral structures.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of scoline is?
questions.solution:
Ans: D
Mechanism of action of muscle relaxants:
1: Depolarising muscle relaxants ( DMR) : scoline : acts by partial agonism of acetylcholine receptor causing persistent depolarisation of the Ach receptor causing muscle relaxation
2: Non-Depolarising Muscle Relaxant (NDMR): competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptor in post junctional muscle membrane

choices.text: Give a bolus dose of verapamil for arrythmia

questions.text: A 14-year-old is undergoing an urgent laparoscopic appendicectomy. Intraoperatively, persistent tachycardia is noted with a rising end tidal CO2. The temperature has risen from 37.8 to 38.5 °C in 20 minutes. Malignant hyperpyrexia is suspected. You should immediately:
questions.solution:
Ans: D
•	Recognition of malignant hyperpyrexia (MH) is key
•	Unexplained increase in heart rate and end tidal CO2, alongside increased oxygen requirement, and possibly late-onset temperature rises, should prompt recognition of MH.
•	Volatile anaesthesia should be discontinued, and anaesthesia maintained via intravenous agents. 
•	The patient should be ventilated with 100% oxygen via a clean circuit and preferably via a dedicated anaesthetic machine that has not been in contact with volatile anaesthetic agents. 
•	While hyperventilation may help control respiratory acidosis, it alone is not adequate management. 
•	Close liaison with the surgical team is vital – explain that there is an anaesthetic emergency and that completion of surgery should be expedited, or, if feasible, surgery abandoned. 
•	In this case, conversion to an open procedure may be warranted depending on surgical experience/expertise. 
•	The recommended bolus dose is now 2.5 mg.kg–1 of dantrolene with further boluses up to 10 mg.kg–1 every 5 mins till the control of symptoms and followed by 1mg/kg infusion given over 6 hours for at least 24-48 hours.
•	Active cooling should be initiated.
•	Soda bicarbonate should be used to counter metabolic acidosis
•	All Anti-arrhythmics can be used except calcium channel blockers (cause hyperkalaemia)
•	Hyperkalemia is countered using glucose+insulin infusion

questions.text: Spinal anesthesia is typically administered into which space?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) Subarachnoid space

 Explanation:  Spinal anesthesia is injected into the subarachnoid space, where the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is located. This allows the local anesthetic to block the nerve roots, producing anesthesia

questions.text: Rocuronium:
questions.solution: Ans: D • Rocuronium (Rapid Onset curonium) is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker in the aminosteroid class. • It undergoes almost exclusive hepatobiliary excretion with no metabolism. • Rapid onset (60-90 s) can be achieved with 0.9– 1.2 mg.kg–1, and this dose may be used as part of a ‘modified’ RSI, where there is a reason to avoid suxamethonium. • Like the long-acting aminosteroid pancuronium, rocuronium is a mild vagolytic, so may increase heart rate and blood pressure, although this effect is less pronounced than with pancuronium. • Indeed, it may be preferred to atracurium, which is more associated with histamine release.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT monitored by capnography?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  D) depth of muscle relaxation
 Explanation:  Capnography primarily monitors end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) and indirectly provides information about ventilation and respiratory rate

questions.text: What is the most reliable site to measure core temperature during general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A

Different temperature monitoring sites are used for core body measurement:
A: Pulmonary artery catheter: also know as Swan Ganz catheter is most invasive and gold standard method of measuring the core body temperature.

B: distal esophagus: this is most commonly used technique. A probe in distal third of esophagus measures the temperature near right heart

C: tympanic membrane

D: nasopharynx

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is anesthetized for resection of a temporal lobe tumour. Preoperatively, he is lethargic and confused possibly due to raised intracranial pressure. which of the following would be the MOST appropriate drug to control systemic arterial blood pressure during direct laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
(A) 
•	Except propofol, all the drugs listed are potent cerebral vasodilators capable of further increasing ICP, which would be highly undesirable in this patient. 
•	Propofol is a potent cerebral vasoconstrictor that will decrease the ICP.
•	It has rapid onset of action and ultra short duration of action.
•	Rest all the drugs wont be very useful 
•	Ketamine: cerebral vasodilator and sympathomimetic
•	Sodium nitroprusside & Nitrous oxide: cerebral vasodilator


Drugs useful to prevent stress response to laryngoscopy and intubation are
lignocaine, opioids, nitroglycerine, calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem and β-blockers such as esmolol have been tried.

questions.text: Pulse oximetry estimates which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C) SaO2

 Explanation:  Pulse oximetry measures the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin (SaO2) in the blood. It provides a non-invasive estimate of the percentage of hemoglobin saturated with oxygen but does not measure PaO2 directly.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method used to know depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution: Ans: A • Bispectral Index (BIS) is the most common depth of anesthesia monitor • It is a frontal processed EEG. • It is displayed a number ranging between 0 to 100. • Depth of anesthesia is decided by the number on monitor  0: flat line on EEG  0-20: burst suppression  20-40: very deep general anesthesia  40-60: adequate general anesthesia  60-80: mild sedation  80- 100: awake

choices.text: Less potent and so less laudonosine production

questions.text: Cisatracurium is preferred over atracurium because?
questions.solution:
Ans: B
•	Atracurium is an amino steroid Non depolarising Muscle Relaxant which a mixture of 10 different isomers.
•	Atracurium is metabolised by 2 organ independent processes of nonspecific esterase hydrolysis (66%) and Hoffmann’s elimination (33%).
•	Hoffman’s elimination is a non-enzymatic organ independent spontaneous degradation of the molecule under physiological ph. and temperature.
•	Atracurium is associated with histamine release and therefore causes transient hypotension, reflex tachycardia and bronchoconstriction.
•	Cisatracurium is a pure cis isomer of atracurium and has some difference in properties as compared to atracurium.

1.	It is 4 times more potent than atracurium
2.	It is metabolized by only Hoffmann’s elimination
3.	No histamine release
4.	No risk of laudonosine toxicity

questions.text: Which of the following factors in a patient’s history would concern you with regards to increased risk of aspiration except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C
•	“Mendelson syndrome” was initially described as aspiration of gastric contents causing a chemical pneumonitis characterized by fever, cyanosis, hypoxia, pulmonary edema, and potential death

•	Chemical pneumonitis is more likely following the aspiration of gastric contents if pH is less than 2.5 and volume is at least 0.4 mL/kg body weight

Risk factors can be split into a number of categories:
• Delayed gastric emptying (pain, trauma, opioids, alcohol)
• Medical conditions (GORD, hiatus hernia, diabetic neuropathy, neurological/ neuromuscular disease)
• Acute illness (bowel obstruction/ileus, metabolic derangement, impaired consciousness)
•	Dehydration doesn’t have any effect on the risk of aspiration

questions.text: Which of the following factors increases the onset time of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C) Lower tissue pH

 Explanation:  A lower tissue pH (as seen in inflamed or infected tissues) reduces the amount of local anesthetic available in its non-ionized, active form, thus slowing the onset of action

choices.text: Activation of GABA receptors in brain

questions.text: Mechanism of action of curare is?
questions.solution:
Ans: C
•	The skeletal muscle relaxants that are used for muscle relaxation for anesthesia are derived from a south American arrow poison known as curare.
•	These curares are competitive inhibitors of acetylcholine at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at post junctional membrane of neuromuscular junction.
•	They bind to the alpha subunit of the nicotinic receptor and blocks it causing the cessation of neuronal transmission from a peripheral motor nerve to the muscle end plate.
•	This causes relaxation of muscles.

questions.text: Most common ophthalmic complication under anesthesia is?
questions.solution:
Ans: C
•	Most common ophthalmic complication under anesthesia is corneal abrasions due to drying of cornea due to loss of lacrimation.
•	Most common cause of blindness after surgery is ischemic optic neuropathy.
•	It happens due to prone position

choices.text: spontaneous breathing under the effect of muscle relaxation

questions.text: Identify the capnogram?
questions.solution: Ans: B

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient is posted for laparoscopic appendicectomy. The child gives a history of cyanotic spells from childhood. The mother tells that her child has a heart condition. Which of the following would be a preferred drug for induction of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: B
Ketamine
•	It is a phencyclidine derivative used for induction of anaesthesia
•	Pharmacodynamic effects:
•	Cardiovascular system: indirect sympathomimetic effects causing hypertension and tachycardia.
•	Respiratory system: minimum depression of breathing
•	CNS: increase in icp and cmro2
•	Uterus: uterotonic effect
•	Agent of choice in a patient with cyanotic congenital heart disease because increase in SVR ( systemic vascular resistance) decreases the right to left shunt and improves oxygenation.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics has the longest duration of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) Bupivacaine

 Explanation:  Bupivacaine has a longer duration of action compared to lidocaine, mepivacaine, and procaine, making it useful for prolonged procedures and postoperative analgesia.

questions.text: Which of the inhalational anesthetic uses special vaporizer?
questions.solution:
Ans: A
Desflurane has special physical properties.
It has a very high vapour pressure ( 660 mmhg) and a very low boiling point ( 23.5 deg Celsius)
Due to this, it cant be delivered precisely using a conventional vaporizer and so we use a special vaporizer for delivering desflurane called as TEC 6 vaporizer.
